NAVY TROUNCES BALL TEAM
Midshipmen Roll Up Big Score in
Loosely Played Game—Hopkins
Pitchers Easily Hit—Wood
Stars With Bat.

In a ragged long-drawn-out
contest, the Navy ball team
handed out a severe lacing to the
Black and Blue last Wednesday,
22-10. Judefind started the game
on the mound but was easily hit,
allowing six bingles in the first
inning. Love, who was sent in
to relieve him, was as readily
solved and was also wild, issuing
several passes and allowing seven
safeties. With two down in the
fourth after several runs had been
scored, Eddie Hooper sent Wallace in to take up the twirling,
and he pitched a very creditable
game, letting the midshipmen
down with five hits for the remainder of the battle.
Bill Wood, who caught in the
absence of Benson, starred with
the willow, gathering three safeties in four attempts, while Wallace did his best to win his own
game, collecting two hits in four
times at bat.
Doyle pointed the way in the
vy hitting, connecting safely
six times in seven tries, and denting the rubber four times.

Society of Engineering Education to
Convene at Hopkins.

The Society for the Promotion
of Engineering Education will
meet in Annual Convention in
this University June 25-28, inclusive.
As its name suggests, this
Society devotes itself exclusively
to the consideration, discussion
and improvement of the methods
of educating engineers. It has a
long history, having been organized more than twenty-five years
ago, and its membership includes
the leading engineering educators
of the country, as well as many
others interested in the purposes
of the Society. It is expected
that about one hundred and fifty
members will attend the convention.
. The sessions of the convention
will be held in the lecture hall
of the Mechanical and Electrical
Engineering Building. There will
he morning and afternoon sessions each day. On Wednesday
afternoon, June 25, President
Goodnow will deliver an address
of welcome and in the succeeding
sessions papers will be presented
by leading educators and others.
On Thursday evening the annual
dinner will, be held at the Baltimore Country Club, and on Friday afternoon the membership
will visit the U. S. Naval Academy, at Annapolis. The complete
program is not yet available.

Aldred Lecturer Speaks on Telephone
Difficulties.

On May 14th the last of this
term's series of Aldred Lectures
of the Engineering Department,
on "Disturbing Currents in Telephone Systems," was given by Mr.
John B. Taylor, consulting engineer, of the General Electric
Company.
The lecturer began with an explanation of the operation of a
telephone of the .simplest type.
He described the transmitters of
the magneto and of the battery
forms, and showed the superiority
of the latter, as embodied in the
present microphone transmitter.
From this he passed on to the
modern exchanges, with the large
switchboards and complicated
wiring systems.
A description of the various
wave forms then followed. The
purity of the sound received at
the end of the line is affected by
changes in the shapes of the
waves, caused by disturbing currents. These result in increased
time of sending messages and in
psychological effects on the users,
due to the fact that the disturbances are separate sounds rather
than distortions of the voice
sounds.
The causes that disturb the
telephone services are classed as
those that put the line out of service, those that ring the signalling

rause occasional or continuous
sounds in the receivers. The latter are divided into natural

Hopkins Concert on May 23rd.

Inv I tations and reserved seats
are being sent out for the first
concert by the Johns Hopkins
orchestra, sixty musicians, Charles
H. Bochau, conductor. The Glee
Club will assist in the program.
The concert will be
given in McCoy Hall, Friday
evening, May 23, at 8:30 p. m.,
promptly, and is given under the
auspices of the John's Hopkins
Musical Association. The officers
of the Association are as follows:
E. L. Turnbull, president; C. T.
Tilden, treasurer; Miss C. E.
Montague, secretary. Trustees,
President, Frank J. Goodnow ;
Dr. Murray P. Brush, Prof.
Charles J. Tilden, Prof. David M.
Robinson, Dr. Thomas R. Brown,
Dr. Thomas S. Cullen, Capt.
George R. Guild, Edwin Litchfield Turnbull, Frank B. Cunn,
Frederic H. Gottleib, Philip Sidney Morgan.
A section of the hall will be
reserved for members of the
Faculty and invited guests, and
tickets may be obtained by students for the remainder of the
seating capacity.

Freshmen Out-Talk Sophs.

Before a very small, but exclusive, audience the Freshmen debators defeated the Sophomores
unanimously, Saturday evening.
The subject under discussion was:
"Resolved, That the Peace Conference Grant Autonomy to Armenia
Under the Guardianship of the
United States." '21 fought for
the affirmative, but the Freshmen
had the "dope" on them and were
able to defeat them i flout much
difficulty. Watkins, for the youngsters, proved to be the most able
and versatile talker.
The teams were: '21, Stein,
Mendes and Zubin; '22, Cotton,
Watkins and Goetz.
The judges were Professor Herbert E. Greene, Mr. William
Wanlass and Mr. Wilhelm Schulz.

1920 Chooses "Hullabaloo" Board And
Elects Student Council.

Four members of the "1920
Hullabaloo" Board were chosen
by the Junior Class at the meeting held May 13. The successful
candidates of the election were:
Warren Driver, Francis Herring,
John H. Lewin and Frederick
Torsch. Captained by Millard
Foard as editor-in-chief these men
are expected to put out an attractive Year Book. Warren M.
Driver will be business manager.
Foard has already laid plans and
has begun to collect material.
He held a meeting of the board
last week.
Samuel Silberstein, L. G.
Smith and Francis Townsend
were elected to represent the
class on the. Student Council. A
committee composed of Silberstein, Orne and Gardner were in
charge of collecting the banquet
funds.

Last Cotillion Takes Place on June 6th.

The Johns Hopkins Cotillion
Board has announced that the
final cotillion of the season will
be held on Friday, June 6, in the
Civil Engineering Hall. It is
planning to make the affair the
social climax of the season, with
original decorations, soul-stirring
music, and refreshments on the
same scale. The members of thn
faculty and their wives are all to
be invited as chaperons. Those
who attend the festivities, both
professors and students, are assured of obtaining inspiral ion
enough to carry them, with ease,
through the period of trial and
tribulation of the examinations.

NAVY TROUNCES BALL TEAM
Midshipmen Roll Up Big Score in
Loosely Played Game—Hopkins
Pitchers Easily Hit—Wood
Stars With Bat.

In a ragged long-drawn-out
contest, the Navy ball team
handed out a severe lacing to the
Black and Blue last Wednesday,
22-10. Judefind started the game
on the mound but was easily hit,
allowing six bingles in the first
inning. Love, who was sent in
to relieve him, was as readily
solved and was also wild, issuing
several passes and allowing seven
safeties. With two down in the
fourth after several runs had been
scored, Eddie Hooper sent Wallace in to take up the twirling,
and he pitched a very creditable
game, letting the midshipmen
down with five hits for the remainder of the battle.
Bill Wood, who caught in the
absence of Benson, starred with
the willow, gathering three safeties in four attempts, while Wallace did his best to win his own
game, collecting two hits in four
times at bat.
Doyle pointed the way in the
vy hitting, connecting safely
six times in seven tries, and denting the rubber four times.

Society of Engineering Education to
Convene at Hopkins.

The Society for the Promotion
of Engineering Education will
meet in Annual Convention in
this University June 25-28, inclusive.
As its name suggests, this
Society devotes itself exclusively
to the consideration, discussion
and improvement of the methods
of educating engineers. It has a
long history, having been organized more than twenty-five years
ago, and its membership includes
the leading engineering educators
of the country, as well as many
others interested in the purposes
of the Society. It is expected
that about one hundred and fifty
members will attend the convention.
. The sessions of the convention
will be held in the lecture hall
of the Mechanical and Electrical
Engineering Building. There will
he morning and afternoon sessions each day. On Wednesday
afternoon, June 25, President
Goodnow will deliver an address
of welcome and in the succeeding
sessions papers will be presented
by leading educators and others.
On Thursday evening the annual
dinner will, be held at the Baltimore Country Club, and on Friday afternoon the membership
will visit the U. S. Naval Academy, at Annapolis. The complete
program is not yet available.

Aldred Lecturer Speaks on Telephone
Difficulties.

On May 14th the last of this
term's series of Aldred Lectures
of the Engineering Department,
on "Disturbing Currents in Telephone Systems," was given by Mr.
John B. Taylor, consulting engineer, of the General Electric
Company.
The lecturer began with an explanation of the operation of a
telephone of the .simplest type.
He described the transmitters of
the magneto and of the battery
forms, and showed the superiority
of the latter, as embodied in the
present microphone transmitter.
From this he passed on to the
modern exchanges, with the large
switchboards and complicated
wiring systems.
A description of the various
wave forms then followed. The
purity of the sound received at
the end of the line is affected by
changes in the shapes of the
waves, caused by disturbing currents. These result in increased
time of sending messages and in
psychological effects on the users,
due to the fact that the disturbances are separate sounds rather
than distortions of the voice
sounds.
The causes that disturb the
telephone services are classed as
those that put the line out of service, those that ring the signalling

rause occasional or continuous
sounds in the receivers. The latter are divided into natural

reserved for members of the

tickets may be obtained by students for the remainder of the

Freshmen Out-Talk Sophs.

Before a very small, but exclusive, audience the Freshmen debators defeated the Sophomores
unanimously, Saturday evening.
The subject under discussion was:
"Resolved, That the Peace Conference Grant Autonomy to Armenia
Under the Guardianship of the
United States." '21 fought for
the affirmative, but the Freshmen
had the "dope" on them and were
able to defeat them i flout much
difficulty. Watkins, for the youngsters, proved to be the most able
and versatile talker.
The teams were: '21, Stein,
Mendes and Zubin; '22, Cotton,
Watkins and Goetz.
The judges were Professor Herbert E. Greene, Mr. William
Wanlass and Mr. Wilhelm Schulz.

1920 Chooses "Hullabaloo" Board And
Elects Student Council.

Four members of the "1920
Hullabaloo" Board were chosen
by the Junior Class at the meeting held May 13. The successful
candidates of the election were:
Warren Driver, Francis Herring,
John H. Lewin and Frederick
Torsch. Captained by Millard
Foard as editor-in-chief these men
are expected to put out an attractive Year Book. Warren M.
Driver will be business manager.
Foard has already laid plans and
has begun to collect material.
He held a meeting of the board
last week.
Samuel Silberstein, L. G.
Smith and Francis Townsend
were elected to represent the
class on the. Student Council. A
committee composed of Silberstein, Orne and Gardner were in
charge of collecting the banquet
funds.

Last Cotillion Takes Place on June 6th.

The Johns Hopkins Cotillion
Board has announced that the
final cotillion of the season will
be held on Friday, June 6, in the
Civil Engineering Hall. It is
planning to make the affair the
social climax of the season, with
original decorations, soul-stirring
music, and refreshments on the
same scale. The members of thn
faculty and their wives are all to
be invited as chaperons. Those
who attend the festivities, both
professors and students, are assured of obtaining inspiral ion
enough to carry them, with ease,
through the period of trial and
tribulation of the examinations.
